item.title: 2016-09-07 - Project Presentation: Module 1
item.description:
Project Description

from Fredrik

In the 2D-illustration the space is created between the objects ”balls”. However the idea of the balls are dependent on the viewers perspective and relation to its surrounding. If you don’t have any relation to a object you will compare it to similar objects.

The balls can be viewed upon two ways. That the balls are the same size and they will seam to be more or less distant from the viewers point of view. i.e.a relation in depth. Or that the balls have different sizes and only relate to one and other.

The grid in the backgrund will enhance the feeling of depth and give the viewer a better idea of the balls relation to the space. This because the backgrund will work as a object itself.

In our project the each ball and color can represent a specific devise and the size by the collected amount of bluetooth signals.

  • Avoidance game. BT others is to be avoided.

Notes:

  • Distance

Sound:

  • Molecule movement => virbrations => sound

Difference IR vs BT:

  • Bluetooth: shorter wavelength => Through walls, bend
  • Infrared: directional => Can’t go through walls.

Questions:

  • Where can I find bluetooth?
  • How much bluetooth devices is there in location X? (density)

Discussion at 14.00:

Six aspects of coupling:

time, direction, …

Where does it fit in? What can you do?

Feeling: Stimulation, security, meaning?

Interactive attribute: What does slow mean to this? Fast? Aspects of bluetooth in the now?

How do we feel? How can you build something for coupling people at difference spaces?

Different spaces - how do I feel that I’m on 4th floor. Feeling secure while in different places from eachother.

Interactivity & Module 1 Intro NI:B0308

Reading 1: Wensveen et al “Interaction Frogger: a Design framework to couple action and function through feedback”

  • What are the challenges of natural coupling when it comes to interaction design?
  • Pick a non-digital tool and attempt to identify its six aspects of coupling.
  • Try the same with an app or physical product with digital interactivity
  • How do you think this work is useful for the designer?
  • What is the contribution of the paper? What new knowledge is it adding?

item.title: 2016-08-29: Introduction day
item.description:
Introductions OR:B441

Reading 1: Schön - Design as Reflective Conversation with the Materials of the Design Situation

  • How does Schön describe the design knowledge?
  • Can you think of other examples of ‘knowing-in-action’ from your every day life?
  • For Schön, what form does a ‘design situation’ take, and how do we grasp it?
  • Briefly describe Schön’s account of seeing/moving/seeing
  • How do you think this process relates to sketching with digital materials, such as code?
  • How is progress made in a design situation, according to Schön?
